title: How did crocodiles survive the asteroid that killed the dinosaurs?About 66 million years ago, dinosaurs ruled Earth. But when a massive asteroid slammed into shallow sea, massive amounts of dust was thrown into the sky, blocking out the Sun for many months.
subject: Science

title: Could dinosaurs still exist somewhere in the world?It’s fun to imagine secret dinosaur survivors living today, hidden in a remote corner of Earth. But the truth of who made it through the extinction event 66 million years ago may surprise you.
subject: Science

title: Eat The InvadersHost Tony Armstrong — with the help of scientists, land carers, an artist and a chef — investigates different invasive species across Australia and the various strategies being used to manage their populations. goes here
subject: Science

title: Eat the Invaders: Feral catsTony Armstrong visits Yookamurra Sanctuary in South Australia, a dedicated safe haven for some of the country's most threatened species to speak with wildlife ecologist and ranger Dr Aly Ross about feral cats.Duration: 2 minutes 2 seconds2m 2s
subject: Science

title: Eat the Invaders: New food industriesTony Armstrong investigates the possibility of creating a sustainable camel meat industry in Australia as a solution to controlling their population numbers. Duration: 1 minute 55 seconds1m 55s
subject: Science

title: Eat the Invaders: RabbitsTony Armstrong and CSIRO scientist Dr Tanja Strive discuss the introduction of rabbits to Australia, why they are classified as an invasive species and the impacts they are having on the environment.Duration: 1 minute 46 seconds1m 46s
subject: Science

title: Eat the Invaders: The taste testTony Armstrong interviews children in Winchelsea, Victoria, about their thoughts on eating rabbit, and he keeps them company while they taste rabbit for the first time!Duration: 2 minutes 27 seconds2m 27s
subject: Science

title: Eat the Invaders: DeerTony Armstrong is in Tasmania where he speaks to Professor Chris Johnson from the University of Tasmania about the complexity of managing wild deer populations in Australia.Duration: 2 minutes 14 seconds2m 14s
subject: Science

title: Eat the Invaders: A feast at MONAAt the Museum of Old and New Art in Tasmania, artist Kirsha Kaechele and chef Vince Trim prepare a feast made of carp.Duration: 1 minute 2 seconds1m 2s
subject: Science

title: Eat the Invaders: Cane toadsTony Armstrong discusses why cane toads are considered an invasive species in Australia. In this video, he visits a group of women in Boonah, Queensland, who dedicate their free time to catching cane toads to control their population.Duration: 57 seconds57s
subject: Science

title: Eat the Invaders: CamelsIn central Western Australia, Tony Armstrong speaks with cattle farmer Jack Carmody about controlling the wild camel population at his family's farm, Prenti Downs Station.Duration: 54 seconds54s
subject: Science

title: Eat the Invaders: The Kiwirrkurra RangersTony Armstrong visits one of the most remote communities in Australia: Kiwirrkurra, in the Gibson Desert to learn First Nations practices of invasive species management from the Kiwirrkurra rangers — the greatest feral cat hunters on the planet!Duration: 3 minutes 8 seconds3m 8s
subject: Science

title: Eat the Invaders: CarpIn this video, Tony visits Coorong (Kurangk) in South Australia. He speaks to commercial fisherman Glen Hill about carp while fishing on the Murray River.Duration: 1 minute 34 seconds1m 34s
subject: Science

title: 10 ideas for teaching kids about sustainable livingIt’s important that children understand the concept of sustainable living from an early age, and there are many easy things you can do to create teachable moments.

title: Does space go on forever?The part of space we can see is called the observable universe and it's 93 billion light years from one side to the other. But exactly how big is space, and does it go on forever? An astronomer explains.

title: Want kids to be healthy eaters? The words you use at the table have a big influence on themThe secret to healthy eating is through the power of words and the magic of connection. title: This animated series on megafauna brings extinct animals to lifeABC Education's new six-part animation series helps students learn about the unique megafauna that once roamed Australia. title: How can Aboriginal knowledge expand our understanding of the past?“It’s important when we talk about megafauna that Aboriginal knowledge is always in the discussion, because this knowledge is just as important as Western science,” Jacinta Koolmatrie writes.

title: Diprotodon: Not a wombatHow big was Australia's most famous extinct megafaunal mammal Diprotodon optatum? Be amazed by the answer and other cool Diprotodon facts discovered by palaeontologists.Duration: 6 minutes 33 seconds6m
subject: Science

title: Thylacoleo: The wild cardDid Australia's fierce marsupial predator Thylacoleo carnifex have the most powerful bite of any living or extinct mammal? How do palaeontologists use fossils to answer this question? Duration: 5 minutes 29 seconds5m
subject: Science

title: Procoptodon: King of roosWhy is Australia's extinct kangaroo, Procoptodon goliah, called the T-rex of roos? What fossil evidence caused palaeontologists to give it that nickname?Duration: 5 minutes 52 seconds5m

subject: Science

title: Finding Thylacoleo fossils in cavesDr Liz Reed loves finding fossils, and she loves caving. subject: Science

title: Getting into GenyornisDr Phoebe McInerney and Associate Professor Trevor Worthy are palaeontologists who study the fossils of extinct birds. subject: Science

subject: Science
